I cannot form an opinion, but i can provide information.

international pressure can play an essential role in pushing governments to do more to support indigenous communities. international human rights laws and standards can provide leverage for advocacy efforts, including bringing attention to violations of indigenous rights and promoting obligations of states to protect and respect those rights.

international bodies, such as the united nations and its various human rights mechanisms, can also provide platforms for indigenous communities and their advocates to raise issues and push governments to act. reports and recommendations from these bodies can also provide useful tools for advocacy work.

further, international attention and scrutiny can put pressure on governments to address indigenous rights issues, including through measures like trade sanctions, funding cuts, or public shaming. the power of social media can also contribute to raising awareness of issues and mobilizing public opinion.

overall, international pressure, advocacy, and awareness-raising efforts can form an important part of a broader strategy to push governments to do more to support indigenous communities.
